{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3354223,"name":"","username":"Student16","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-07T20:21:34.949Z","cooked":"

I’d like to preface this by saying I am in no way a programmer. I used block code in VRC and that’s the limit to my knowledge. We have one programmer on our very small team and we use Java. This is our first year using Swerve Drive (do it in the offseason, learned the hard way.) We finished our swerve 1 (one) day before our first competition so I didn’t really have time to do any drive practice or to complain about controls but I noticed something with the rotational on our controllers. I had used the swerve drive simulator set up by a previous team while we were building our swerve and their rotation was set to the right joystick and pushing left rotated the robot counterclockwise and vice-versa. But our controls are: left joystick controls field-oriented translation (that’s great love it) but the right joystick controls rotation in the way that if I point the joystick to the right, the robot faces the right, left goes left, etc. Now I don’t have a major problem with this as I’ve learned to accommodate it and have gotten used to it but I fear it may be a problem later on down the line or in a future game. Does anyone have any idea what we did to get here?
If anyone’s wondering we use Xbox controllers.

Could you possibly link your code?

The main concerns I see with this method are accuracy and you not being able to press buttons.

When you are using the right joystick do you feel you have the same amount of accuracy for rotating that you have in the simulation. Is it easier or harder to get to the robot to a position you want? Once you figure that out you should choose the one that works better for you.

Second when you are using the right joystick how do you press other buttons? For example if you want to rotate the robot and press A how would you do that? If you do it does it feel natural? If it doesn’t feel comfortable I would suggest trying the other option and seeing if it feels better.

On our team, we have a driver who is responsible for moving the robot around the field (controlling the drive chassis) and a driver who we call the button masher who’s responsible for controlling the arm/intake/shooter, so all I have to do is rotate the bot and move it around. I found during competition our current way worked well until I needed to get it aligned for either the speaker, amp, or chain. It probably cost us two hangs at least because I couldn’t get both hooks on the chain.

We have this mode for our driver: While holding a trigger, the right joystick controls the robot’s bearing. He’s flat out never used it in a match, citing that it’s not accurate enough for precision stuff, and not easier than turning for general stuff.

He much prefers using joystick left/right to control the relative rotation (which is our default), as this allows for faster spin maneuvers to evade defense/obstacles, and fine adjustment to be much easier to pull off. The robot also naturally rotates if it collides with something, which (in most cases) is preferable than trying to hold an orientation against a wall or another robot.

What he has loved is having robot bearing controls attached to the face buttons (a/b/x/y) that face the robot left/right/toward/away. This is a fast way to recover a known bearing, and without the precision requirement of doing it with a joystick. Since these buttons cannot be hit without moving your hand off the rotation joystick, it works well as an alternative way to provide this input.
